cards.front: What is a general obligation bond (GO bond)?
cards.back: Backed by the full faith, credit, and taxing power of the issuer. GO bonds are typically backed by tax revenue

Backed by revenue from a specific source, such as a public hospital, a toll bridge, or a sports arena. Revenue bonds are not backed by the full faith and credit of the issuer and are often issued by a separate authority such as a transportation authority
A legal requirement for corporate issuers under the Trust Indenture Act of 1939. Municipal issues are exempt from this act
It is legally binding on the issuer
Fully authorized and issued by municipality
The interest is exempt from federal tax under current law
The opinion will be qualified if the counsel finds a problem. The qualifier will state that there is a legal uncertainty of which any purchaser should be aware
The bond counsel determines that they have found no problems with the issue
Issuers want an unqualified legal opinion because this means there are no outstanding legal issues associated with the issue
New streetlights or sidewalks may be put in one area, and only that area is assessed higher taxes to pay for the improvement

The state of New York (NY) assumed the moral obligation to pay if the city of NY could not. NY's state legislature was authorized, but not obligated, to provide the funds needed to service the debt, if necessary

The interest income received from corporate issues is taxable at the federal, state, and local level. Interest income received from the privatized agency issuers, such as FNMA (Fannie Mae) and FHLMC (Freddie Mac), is taxed the same way
Exemptions, the role of a bond counsel, bond contract, bond resolution, common practices
Backed by taxes including ad valorem taxes; concepts including mill rates, debt limits

cards.front: What is Municipal debt tax status?
cards.back: Interest income is exempt from federal tax, triple tax exempt for in-state residents, territory bonds triple tax exempt for all

cards.front: Revenue Bonds: What is the backed by ad valorem taxes, and by the full faith and credit of the municipality?
cards.back: Backed by revenues from a specific project (e.g., sports arena)

cards.front: Revenue Bonds: What is the issued to fund a municipality's budget?
cards.back: Issued to fund a specific project

cards.front: Revenue Bonds: What is the debt limits can apply?
cards.back: Debt limits do not apply

cards.front: Revenue Bonds: What is the typically, safer than revenue bonds?
cards.back: Typically, riskier than GO bonds

cards.front: Test-Taking Tip: What should you remember?
cards.back: Issuers want an unqualified legal opinion because this means there are no outstanding legal issues associated with the issue.

cards.front: What are the characteristics of municipal bonds?
cards.back:
• Interest income not taxed at the federal level
• Exempt from registration, but not from anti-fraud requirements
• Come with an official statement instead of a prospectus
• Good for investors in higher tax brackets
• Typically, lower yields than corporate bonds, but higher than Treasuries
• Typically, less risky than corporate bonds
• Good for portfolio diversification
the Municipal Securities Rulemaking Board

cards.front: What is Characteristics of Money Market Instruments?
cards.back: Understanding what makes these securities unique

cards.front: What is Types of Money Market Instruments?
cards.back: From Treasury bills to commercial paper

cards.front: What is Long-Term Certificates of Deposit?
cards.back: Why they're different from traditional money market instruments

cards.front: What is When the Fed buys money market instruments?
cards.back: It puts cash into banks, increasing credit availability (loosening monetary policy)

cards.front: What is When the Fed sells money market instruments?
cards.back: It drains cash from banks, decreasing credit availability (tightening monetary policy)

cards.front: What is CDs are subject to market risk?
cards.back: Their value fluctuates with interest rates

cards.front: What is Pre-maturity sale prices may be less than purchase price?
cards.back: Selling before maturity could mean taking a loss

cards.front: What is CDs have a limited secondary market?
cards.back: They're not as liquid as Treasury securities

cards.front: What is Callable CDs are subject to reinvestment risk?
cards.back: If called, you might have to reinvest at lower rates

cards.front: What is Step-up/step-down CD yields may not reflect current market rates?
cards.back: The predetermined rate adjustments might lag the market

cards.front: What is FDIC insurance only applies if titled in the customer's name?
cards.back: And only up to $250,000 per depositor, per institution

All employees must be treated equally under the Act. These plans must be available to all eligible employees and not just highly paid executives
Employers must offer their established plan to any employee who works more than 1,000 hours per year and has been with the company for more than 12 months
Employees must earn their employer contributions over a reasonable time period. Once the contributions are fully vested, the account is the property of the employee, even upon leaving the firm
Employees are 100% vested after three years
Employer contributions vest at 20% per year of service after the first year, with 100% vesting after six years
The plan trustee must manage the assets of the plan in the best interests of all participants. Plan assets must be segregated from other company assets
The most common type—a plan for corporate employees in which employees contribute a portion of their wages to individual accounts and where contributions may be matched by their employer
Enable employers to contribute to employee accounts based on corporate profits. Contributions are not guaranteed and may be skipped in years in which the corporation is not profitable

cards.front: What is Life with Period Certain?
cards.back: The insurer pays the annuitant an income during their lifetime. But if the annuitant dies before the period certain expires, payments will continue to be made to a beneficiary

cards.front: What is Joint Life with Last Survivor?
cards.back: This option covers two lifetimes. The insurer will continue paying a benefit until both covered parties have died

cards.back: The cost of the death benefit (the life insurance component)
